questions.question: The change in the equilibrium constant with temperature is described by which equation?
options: Van't Hoff equation
Henderson-Hasselbalch equation
Nernst equation
Arrhenius equation

questions.question: What does the Beer-Lambert law relate in spectrophotometry?
options: Concentration of a solution to its absorbance
Temperature of a solution to its absorbance
pH of a solution to its absorbance
Conductivity of a solution to its absorbance
questions.correct_answer: Concentration of a solution to its absorbance

questions.question: What is the formula for calculating the standard deviation?
options: Square root of (sum of (x - mean)^2 / n)
Square root of (sum of (x - mean) / n)
Square root of (sum of (x - mean)^2 / (n - 1))
Square root of (sum of (x - mean) / (n - 1))

questions.question: What does the term 'limit of detection' mean in analytical chemistry?
options: The highest concentration that can be accurately measured
The lowest concentration that can be accurately measured
The maximum amount of sample that can be analyzed
The minimum amount of sample that can be analyzed
questions.correct_answer: The lowest concentration that can be accurately measured

questions.question: What is the principle of 'stoichiometry' in a chemical reaction?
options: It refers to the mass relationships between reactants and products in a chemical reaction
It refers to the volume relationships between reactants and products in a chemical reaction
It refers to the energy relationships between reactants and products in a chemical reaction
It refers to the temperature relationships between reactants and products in a chemical reaction
questions.correct_answer: It refers to the mass relationships between reactants and products in a chemical reaction

questions.question: In chromatography, what is the stationary phase?
options: The phase that moves along with the sample
The phase that remains fixed and interacts with the sample
The phase that changes the sample properties
The phase that does not interact with the sample
questions.correct_answer: The phase that remains fixed and interacts with the sample

questions.question: What does the 'specific rotation' of a compound refer to in polarimetry?
options: The degree of rotation of plane-polarized light by a solution of the compound
The speed of rotation of plane-polarized light by a solution of the compound
The direction of rotation of plane-polarized light by a solution of the compound
The intensity of rotation of plane-polarized light by a solution of the compound
questions.correct_answer: The degree of rotation of plane-polarized light by a solution of the compound

questions.question: What is the definition of 'pKa' in the context of acid-base equilibria?
options: It is the logarithm of the acid dissociation constant
It is the logarithm of the base dissociation constant
It is the pH at which the acid is half-dissociated
It is the pH at which the base is half-dissociated
questions.correct_answer: It is the logarithm of the acid dissociation constant

questions.question: What is the color change for phenolphthalein in an acid and a base?
options: In acid: colorless, in base: pink
In acid: pink, in base: colorless
In acid: blue, in base: yellow
In acid: yellow, in base: blue
questions.correct_answer: In acid: colorless, in base: pink

questions.question: What is the role of an indicator in a titration process?
options: It accelerates the reaction between the analyte and the titrant
It slows down the reaction between the analyte and the titrant
It signals the end point of the titration by a color change
It provides a medium for the reaction to take place
questions.correct_answer: It signals the end point of the titration by a color change
